tickets.description:
Problem:
To return to a web-page it is necessary to know its url. The page can
be bookmarked, but there is no way of associating the page with the
bookmark.

Suggestion:

the page, either as a URL file in the page directory, or by writing
the URL in a comment in the page html file.

application. It would also be an improvement to use the

whole thing in one directory rather than preserving the 
structure makes this difficult. I realise that this would 
not really be feasible, but possibly keeping the filenames 
and modifying them where necessary to avoid clashes would 
be good. If I just want to keep a copy of a page for 
reference then a Draw file does the job nicely.

tickets.description:
A useful function whilst viewing a web page would be to highlight some text and submit it to a search engine of choice \(eg google\) for a search, producing the results in a new window. 

Ie highlight some text, click menu,
click menu entry: "search www for <text>"
target attribute on an href anchor tag isn't working, at least with target="\_new".

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=453739

We don't currently plan to implement target="\_new", because  
we think it would remove choice from the user. The user can  
choose to open a link in a new window by right-clicking  
instead of left-clicking.  

Other targets that are not a frame in a current frameset  
are also treated as "\_top". 

Please let us know if you have any comments on this 
behaviour. 

James
posts.author: bursa
posts.subject: #19 Target=_new

posts.text:
- **priority**: 5 --> 1
- **assigned_to**: nobody --> bursa
- **status**: open --> open-wont-fix
posts.author: bursa
posts.subject: #19 Target=_new

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=1432144

I appreciate your point, but I use target=\_new \(\_blank is 
equivalent\) when I link large images to thumbnails or text 
links with no surrounding html page. There is no navigation 
from the image other than the browser's 'back' function. 
Therefore I want the images displayed in a new window 
without having to tell the reader than he should do this by 
whatever means his browser allows. This may remove choice 
but it also removes inconvenience and the frustration of 
closing the window only to find that the parent page has 
vanished.
Richard
posts.author: minijem
posts.subject: #19 Target=_new

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=826159

Moved to feature request tracker.

I agree that it should be a user choice to open content in a new window and that current behaviour is fine, for what it's worth.
posts.author: tlsa
posts.subject: #19 Target=_new

posts.text: - **summary**: Target=_new not working --> Target=_new
posts.author: tlsa
posts.subject: #19 Target=_new

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=999199

The new frames code now implements target="\_blank" \("\_new" is not valid HTML, and as such is ignored.\) As this may displease some users/developers it is optional and can be configured in the Content section of the choices UI \(default is on.\)
Base targets such as <base target=\_blank> are also now correctly handled.
posts.author: not_ginger_matt
posts.subject: #19 Target=_new

posts.text: - **status**: open-wont-fix --> closed

Richard

tickets.description:
This request is for a 'clear cache' or 'flush cache' option on the icon bar menu \(for preference\) or at least in Choices.../Cache. In the latter case it could be provided separately for RAM and Disc.

This facility is very useful if you have any problems reloading pages as it lets you start from a known state. For this reason it's also a useful diagnostic facility.

Recently I have been coming across more and more
xhtml documents with xml-stylesheet processing
instructions and no 'corresponding' link element in the
document head.

Would it be possible, since Netsurf already
silently handles xml prologues to handle these
xml-stylesheet processing instructions and convert them
into internal CSS link form?

Keith Hopper
asgard@inspire.net.nz

posts.text:
Logged In: NO 

Apropos of my feature request, I seem to have discovered another potential problem when checking out an Amaya \(totally unrelated\) bug.

Go to the W3C test suite \(http://www.w3c.org/Style/CSS/Test/Css2.1/current/\) and check on the last of the line-height tests.I looked at the two docuemtns - one came up incorrectly - OK work-in-progress. The second one had no colour at all. This seems to be a CDATA problem\! 

Perhaps you might like to convert this into a bug - but it is xhtml related - so I leave it up to you.

Keith Hopper
asgard@inspire.net.nz

tickets.description:
Please could we have a full width horizontal scroll 
bar at the bottom, plus a full width URL/progress/help 
area. The reason for this is that long URLs are 
obscured and it's the right hand end you usually want 
to see most of all. I know the boundary can be moved 
but it's a nuisance to have to do it.

In any case, if the URL is too long to fit into the 
field it would be better if it was right-aligned.
It would be nice if the original names of the objects \(images\) could be kept when doing a full save.
tickets.summary: full save and name of objects

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=826159
Originator: NO

There is now an Inventory file in the full save directory, which matches fullsave filenames to URLs.

It isn't easy to retain the original filenames because a page may load several images with the same filename.

For example if you save http://domain.tld/path/index.html it may use images at:

http://domain.tld/path/image.png
http://domain.tld/images/image.png
http://domain.tld/image.png
http://domain2.tld/image.png

which introduces complications, since they all have the filename "image.png".

Is the Inventory file statisfactory?

tickets.description:
When the title of a webpage contains a top bit char, NS assumes the page is iso-8859-1 encoded \(and ignores the charset specification of the webpage\).

And sometimes the charset is missing \(or even wrong\).
e.g. <http://www.diyanet.gov.tr/DIYANET/2002cocuk/ocak/tilki.htm>
Not selecting the right charset makes it dificult to read a webpage. That's why I would like to be able to force NS to choose a certain charset.
tickets.summary: Forcing NS to use a certain charset

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=1055477

It is possible in Firefox \(View -> Character Encoding\). Are there any plans to add this to NS?

tickets.description:
I would like Netsurf to display the 'alt' text for images \(if any\) when the mouse pointer lingers over them. I believe this behaviour is implemented by various other browsers \(which is why I have come to expect it\).

The simplest implementation would be to send an alternative reply to the HelpRequest messages sent by providers of interactive help. \(Return the 'alt' text of an image instead of the standard "Click SELECT on a link to follow it.." help message.\) I would be quite happy to load \!Help in order to enable this facility, and this approach would automatically implement the user's preferred delay period and display font.

I don't think this would be a good use of the status bar because many images are also links, in which case the \(usually half-width\) status bar will already be full with the destination URI. Also descriptive 'alt' text would be too long.
tickets.summary: Display 'alt' text for image upon mouse-over

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=294680

That would be "title attribute text", not "alt attribute
text" - the former is intended for display via mechanisms
such as tooltips, whereas the latter is a non-standard IEism.
posts.author: dsalt
posts.subject: #29 Display 'alt' text for image upon mouse-over

tickets.description:
The 'out of the box' default font size in NetSurf
\(10pt\) is different from the default font size in the
major browsers. See
http://www.paperweightpress.co.uk/NetSurf/baseFont.htm
for an example.

Since NetSurf doesn't support min-width yet this causes
columns with widths specified in ems to be narrower
than expected. When the column contains an image with a
width specified in pixels, e.g.
http://www.paperweightpress.co.uk/Books/Plays/Skulduggery1.htm,
the image is cropped or overflows the column. \(The
other layout problems on this page are already on your
'To Do' list.\)

Changing the default font size to 12.8pt \(16 pixels per
em\) resolves the problem. Since all the major browsers
have the same 'out of the box' default font size it
might be an idea if NetSurf shipped with the same one.

Regards
Alex Harding
alex AT paperweightpress DOT co DOT uk

You seem to have closed my feature request wothout allowing me to repond.

Target="\_new" is perfectly good html. i regularly use it and don't get any validation errors. It's implemented in all other browsers that support frames. Anyway if you've implemented target="\_blank" it should be trivial to add target="\_new". Don't be so dogmatic\!

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=453739

The validator doesn't check the values of most attributes.

The HTML 4.01 specification states
"Except for the reserved names listed below, frame target 
names must begin with an alphabetic character \(a-zA-Z\). 
User agents should ignore all other target names."

The list does not include \_new.

http://www.w3.org/TR/html401/types\#type-frame-target

Given the wording in the specification I don't think we 
should implement this without a really good reason.

downloadspeed = \(downloadspeed\*7+new downloadspeed\)/8;

An other way of calculating the download speed is:

downloadspeed = total number of bytes downloaded/total
downloadtime.

tickets.description:
A simple addition of the chkspr utility and a line in the Run file of full-save pseudo-applications would allow them to be renamed without losing the custom sprite that NetSurf has taken the trouble to create.  

The utility, when invoked from the Run file, renames the first sprite in the sprite file to the name of the 'application'.

Thus it would not be essential to choose a suitable name instead of the default offered at initial save, but the pseudo-applications could be later renamed at will without losing the iconsprite.

Required:

Include chkspr utility in app directory creation

Add second line invoking "<Obey$Dir>.chkspr" to Run file

J.
johnrw@ukgateway.net
tickets.summary: Add chkspr utility to Full Save

posts.author: nobody
posts.subject: #57 Add chkspr utility to Full Save

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=1384902
Originator: NO

A simpler way of doing this is to copy the \_file\_ ChkSpr \(utility\) to Boot:Library:User, and then add a Boot file to each NetSurf full-save pseudo-application. The Boot file need contain only:

ifthere run:chkspr then chkspr
iconsprites <obey$dir>.\!sprites

An advantage of this is that the Boot file is executed immediately, upon renaming, so that the iconsprites command takes immediate effect.

If the Run file is modified, as suggested, it is necessary to open the full-save file before iconsprites takes effect.

Tony
posts.author: old_coaster
posts.subject: #57 Add chkspr utility to Full Save

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=1768670
Originator: NO

Tony's Boot method /is/ superior, but I think the utility should be provided and referenced within the saved page application, as it would be unreasonable to expect everyone to have the utility in their library.

The full-saved page should be complete in its own right. Tony has agreed in principle to this suggestion.

tickets.description:
Problem:

A full-save application does not contain a \!runimage so that, if the full-save is copied, the datestamp of the original full-save is lost. To determine when it was saved it is then necessary to open the full-save application and inspect the datestamp of the 'index' file.

Some months ago, this problem caused several hundred of my full-saves to be re-stamped with the date of installation of a new hard-drive.

Suggestion:

A full-save application should contain a \!runimage, so that its datestamp will determine the datestamp of the full-save application. The \!runimage could most usefully be a URL file, containing the URL of the page. See too my feature request 'full-save should also save the page url' at http://sourceforge.net/tracker/index.php?func=detail&aid=1365047&group\_id=51719&atid=464315

Tony

tickets.description:

tickets.description:
An idea pinched from StrongED - F4 brings up the search dialogue, why not extend this to have a second F4 keypress when in this dialogue box bring up the last search term used \(as displayed in the drop-down search history\)?   In other words, simply press F4 F4 to repeat last search.

One could have a more 'logical' keypress, such as Ctrl-O for 'old' search, but reusing the same key makes for a convenient shortcut.

Support for standard Netscape API plugins \(as used by Firefox etc\).

This should be able to be broadly added via the existing CONTENT\_PLUGIN interface \(like the Acorn plugin protocol on the RISC OS version\).

Documentation: https://developer.mozilla.org/en/Gecko\_Plugin\_API\_Reference

When saving the location of a page or object please could we have the appropriate filename extension i.e. /uri, /url or /txt instead of the /htm, /jpg or whatever. 
One often wants to save the location with the image and having th filename extensions the same leads to overwriting. I know that RISC OS doesn't bother wil filename extensions but they are good practice and using the wrong extension certainly isn't. I realise too that saving a text location and the text of a page could cause a clash but at lease NS does warn before overwriting.

Netsurf is working nicely on laptops, e.g. Toshiba AC100 with Ubuntu.

But it would be great if it could take up even less screen real estate. By e.g. allowing configuration to:

1\. But the localtion on the top menu bar instead of the button bar, and then disable the button bar.

2\. Make the scrollbar more narrow. Or remove it totally.

Now that we have hotlist title editing back \(thank goodness\!\), can we have support for the Control-U shortcut to delete all text in an icon, to make the task of deleting the default page title and substituting something more meaningful rather less laborious?

I assume the reason it has silently stopped working is that the writable field in the new-style hotlist isn't actually a RISC OS writable icon any more....

NetSurf should have the ability to remember http-authentication passwords and username/password combos entered in web forms, and automatically enter them.  An obvious extension to this would be a form filler, where various fields \(such as address\) could be filled in at the press of a button. 

Usernames and passwords could be stored as encrypted strings in urldb  the passwords don't get saved to disk\) and managed with an interface using the new treeviews.

tickets.description:
See mailing list discussion: http://vlists.pepperfish.net/pipermail/netsurf-users-netsurf-browser.org/2011-February/009951.html

At present, the situation with toolbar editing is as follows:

Clicking Menu over a browser window toolbar and selecting 'Edit toolbar' allows you to add or remove buttons.  This change is immediate and permanent - it applies to that window, all windows opened \(e.g. by target="\_blank"\) from that window, and all windows opened independently in the future, including after quitting and restarting NetSurf.  It does not apply to other windows currently open, or their descendants.

Editing a toolbar in any other window \(e.g. hotlist, cookies\) is also permanent \(inlcuding across restarts\), although in this case only one copy may be present at any time.

Adding or removing gadgets from a browser window toolbar \(buttons/address/throbber\) is not permanent - it applies only to that window and its descendants, not any new windows.  For this to happen, the option 'Display->Save as default' from the main browser area menu must be used.

Adding or removing gadgets from a non-browser toolbar \(in this case just buttons\) is permanent, as above, and these windows do not have a 'Save as default' menu option.

This behaviour is inconsistent and needs changing to one or the other in both cases.

Personally, I don't like the current less than obvious position of the 'Save as default' option, and would prefer that option to be removed and everything to be permanent.  As things stand, this would affect only adding and removing gadgets from the browser toolbar, and not necessitate the addition of a 'Save as default' option to all other windows.

CSS 3 introduced an overflow-y property. If NetSurf could support this then it would make it usable with, for example, Lloyds TSB business internet banking for me once again.
More info: at present when the Lloyds site gives a list \(for example of account payees\) the user can only see the top few entries and the rest is hidden with no way to see in the browser. The page is designed to show a vertical only scroll bar but Netsurf doesn't.
The reason for this is that the HTML \(a simple example attached\) for a limited size element \(the list, eg 90 pixels high\) uses the CSS 2 property overflow:hidden \(thereby ensuring Netsurf shows no scroll bars when the content exceeds the area available\) but also the CSS 3 property overflow-y:scroll \(which is intended to put a scroll bar in vertically\). Web develpers have started doing this because before CSS 3 if they used overflow:auto then browsers would put in both horizontal and vertical scrollbars, whereas they prefer vertical only scrollbars, which they can now get with CSS 3.
Ewen Pring
